The source of the claim: The expert examined the source of the claim, which was a photograph circulating on social media. They identified that the photograph was originally posted by lab technician Katie Corley on her public Facebook page.
Analysis of the photograph: The expert analyzed the content of the photograph and pointed out that it showed two petri dishes, one coughed on by a person not wearing a mask and another coughed on by the same person wearing a mask. They clarified that the petri dish on the right contained "normal oral flora" and not the SARS-CoV-2 virus.
Explanation by the original poster: The expert considered the explanation provided by Katie Corley, who posted the photograph. Corley stated that the petri dish on the right, which showed bacterial growth, demonstrated how masks can lessen the spread of droplets that can carry viruses.
Clarification on the limitations of the: The expert highlighted the limitations of the experiment, as mentioned by Corley. They noted that the experiment used a homemade cloth mask made of disposable lab coat material and blood agar as the medium. Additionally, the expert mentioned that the petri dish on the right appeared "old" or "stale" due to the bacterial growth.
